parameters.name: Workspace
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces'
| project id, name
| order by tolower(name) asc

parameters.name: WSLocation
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces'
| where id == '{Workspace}'
| project location

parameters.name: WSID
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces'
| where id == '{Workspace}'
| project workspaceId = tostring(properties.customerId)

parameters.name: workspaceName
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces'
| where id == '{Workspace}'
| project name

parameters.name: WSRG
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces'
| where id == '{Workspace}'
| project RG = strcat('/subscriptions/', '{Workspace:subscriptionId}', '/resourcegroups/', '{Workspace:resourceGroup}')

content.json:
### Details

This section will serve to set the foundation of the data collection. Filling out this section will create:
1. A data collection endpoint(DCE) that will be used for any and all ingestion.
2. A custom table to house the data for the connector of interest.
3. A data collection rule(DCR) associated with the custom table and the data collection endpoint.

_Destination_ </br>
The destination will serve as where the data is going.
- Custom table: A custom table that will be created and remain custom.
- Custom to native table: A custom log source brought in by the connector and will be sent to a built-in table.
- ASIM table: A built-in table provided by the workspace/Microsoft Sentinel for normalized events. Each table varies depending on the activity type.

To create the components: </br>
1. Select a destination.
2. Follow the instructions listed under the selected destination.
3. Select if a DCE exists.
	- If no, click on the button to open the UI to create a new DCE.
	- Once done, make sure to set the 'DCE Already Exists' toggle to yes.
4. Click on the refresh button within the workbook to force it to fetch the new DCE.
5. Click on the drop down to select the DCE to use.
6. Select if a custom table exists.
	- If no, follow the instructions under the section.
7. Click on the dropdown to select the DCR that was created for the custom table.
8. (Optional) If looking to modify the transformKQL or the output destination of the DCR, set 'Modify Streams' to Yes to open a JSON editor.

### Details

This section will send data to a built-in table as mentioned above. This option requires less work than the custom table route. All that is needed is the data collection endpoint and the data collection rule. 

Data collection endpoints in the list are filtered to be in the same region as the workspace selected at the top of the page. Similarly, data collection rules shown are filtered to be within those that are configured to send to the selected DCE.

If documentation is needed, please see the following:
- [Data Collection Endpoint](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/data-collection-endpoint-overview?tabs=portal)
- [Data Collection Rules](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/data-collection-rule-overview)

### Details

This section will send data to a custom table or will transform a custom log source to be sent to a native table. Since it will leverage custom resources, they will need to be created before the data collection rule can be deployed. 

If the a custom table already exists, set the toggle to yes. If no:
1. Set the toggle to no.
2. If using the UI:
	- Select the first button to open the UI wizard for creating custom tables.
	- Give the table a name.
	- If a DCR exists already, select it from the drop down. If not, create a new DCR that contains 	a name that signals what the source is.
	- Attach the DCR to the DCE for the workspace.
	- Upload a sample file of the data that will be ingested.
	- If transformations need to be made, click on the transformations button to open up the editor. When done, click apply.
	- If done, click review and create > create.
3. If using JSON and API
	- Click on the second button to expand the builder areas.
	- Give the table a name. It must have _CL after the title.
	- Set the table plan.
	- Set the retention for the table.
	- Set the table schema. 
	- (Optional) If the table should be kept for more than 90 days in analytics tier, should be sent to basic tier, or should be archived, modify the items within the JSON to configure the table as needed.
	- Once done, click the button to run the API to create the table. If looking to confirm the creation, click the 'confirm table creation' button to open the tables blade.
	- Next, a DCR is neeed.
	- Give the DCR a name that will signal what the data source is.
	- The remaining components of the DCR will be dynamically populated from the new table values set above.
	- Click the done button to hide the JSON section.
4. Click refresh at the top of the workbook.
5. Set the custom table exists toggle to yes.
6. Select the DCR needed from the drop down list.
7. If sending custom logs to a native table, set the modify streams or destinations toggle to yes.
	- Go into the JSON.
	- If transformKQL and outputStream are not already there, they will need to be added. This will appear as so:
```
                "dataFlows": [ 
                    { 
                        "streams": [ 
                            "Custom-MyTableRawData" 
                        ], 
                        "destinations": [ 
                            "clv2ws1" 
                        ], 
                        "transformKql": "source | project TimeGenerated = Time, Computer, Message = AdditionalContext", 
                        "outputStream": "Microsoft-Syslog" 
                    }, 
                    { 
                        "streams": [ 
                            "Custom-MyTableRawData" 
                        ], 
                        "destinations": [ 
                            "clv2ws1" 
                        ], 
                        "transformKql": "source | where (AdditionalContext has 'malicious traffic!' | project TimeGenerated = Time, Computer, Subject = AdditionalContext", 
                        "outputStream": "Microsoft-SecurityEvent" 
                    } 
                ] 
```

For information on what was used in this section, please see:
- [Data Collection Endpoints](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/data-collection-endpoint-overview?tabs=portal)
- [Data Collection Rules](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/data-collection-rule-overview)
- [Custom tables](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/logs/create-custom-table?tabs=azure-portal-1%2Cazure-portal-2%2Cazure-portal-3#create-a-custom-table)
- [Ingestion time transformation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/essentials/data-collection-transformations)

parameters.name: DCESelect
parameters.label: Select DCE
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.insights/datacollectionendpoints'
| where location == '{WSLocation}'
| extend name = tolower(name)
| project id, name
| order by name asc

parameters.name: dceURL
parameters.query: {"version":"ARMEndpoint/1.0","data":null,"headers":[],"method":"GET","path":"{DCESelect}?api-version=2022-06-01","urlParams":[],"batchDisabled":false,"transformers":[{"type":"jsonpath","settings":{"tablePath":"$.properties.logsIngestion","columns":[{"path":"$.endpoint","columnid":"URL"}]}}]}

parameters.name: WSRetention
parameters.query:
resources
| where type == 'microsoft.operationalinsights/workspaces'
| where id == '{Workspace}'
| project properties.retentionInDays

parameters.name: checkedTableName
parameters.query:
print '{TableName}'
| project Table = iff(print_0 !has '_CL', strcat(print_0, '_CL'), print_0)

content.json:
### Useful Information

The following items define the table: 
- Table Name: The name the new table will have.
- Table Plan: The ingestion plan for the table.
- Tier Retention: If Analytics, the default will be set to 90 days. If more is needed, the number can be modified. If Basic, the default will be set to 8 days.
- Archive Retetnion: Sets the number of days that the data will be archived after the tier retention expires.
- Total Retention: Sum of the tier retention and archive retention.
- Schema: Schema of the table. This must be specified in JSON format.

armActionContext.title: Create {checkedTableName}?

content.json:
### Please Note

Despite the action being successful, the message will claim that it failed regardless. This is an unfortunate limit for some API actions where the portal does not understand how to return a successful call. It is recommended that the 'confirm creation' buttons are used to confirm resource creation. It may take a minute or two to reflect in the UI.

### Useful Information

This section will just store the name of the new data collection rule. The remaining parts such as the data collection endpoint, schema, workspace resource path, etc, will be pulled from the table creation section above.

After the name is entered. Click the deploy button. Once done, make sure to click done at the top. Then, refresh the workbook so that the new DCR associated with the table appears in the list. Make sure to set the 'custom table exists' to yes.

armActionContext.title: Create New Data Collection Rule {newDCRName}?

| project Table = split(Stream, '-')[1]

content.json: ### Now Editing: {DCR2:name}

parameters.name: AuditSchema
parameters.query:
let Audit = datatable(Column:string, Class:string, Type:string, Description:string)[
    "EventMessage", "Optional", "string", "A general message or description, either included in or generated from the record.",
    "EventCount", "Mandatory", "int", "The number of events described by the record.",
    "EventStartTime", "Mandatory", "datetime", "The time in which the event started. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the first event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the TimeGenerated field.",
    "EventEndTime", "Mandatory", "datetime", "The time in which the event ended. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the last event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the TimeGenerated field.",
    "EventType", "Mandatory", "string", "Describes the operation reported by the record. Each schema documents the list of values valid for this field. The original, source specific, value is stored in the EventOriginalType field.",
    "EventSubType", "Optional", "string","Describes a subdivision of the operation reported in the EventType field. Each schema documents the list of values valid for this field. The original, source specific, value is stored in the EventOriginalSubType field.",
    "EventResult", "Mandatory", "string", "One of the following values: Success, Partial, Failure, NA (Not Applicable). The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Alternatively, the source might provide only the EventResultDetails field, which should be analyzed to derive the EventResult value.",
    "EventResultDetails", "Recommended", "string", "Reason or details for the result reported in the EventResult field. Each schema documents the list of values valid for this field. The original, source specific, value is stored in the EventOriginalResultDetails field.",
    "EventUiid", "Recommended", "string", "The unique ID of the record, as assigned by Microsoft Sentinel. This field is typically mapped to the _ItemId Log Analytics field.",
    "EventOriginalUid", "Optional", "string", "A unique ID of the original record, if provided by the source.",
    "EventOriginalType", "Optional", "string", "The original event type or ID, if provided by the source. For example, this field is used to store the original Windows event ID. This value is used to derive EventType, which should have only one of the values documented for each schema."
];
Audit
| extend bag = bag_pack(Column, Class, Type, Description)
| summarize schema = make_bag(bag)

armActionContext.description:
# Actions can potentially modify resources.
## Please use caution and include a confirmation message in this description when authoring this command.

content.json: #### Please note: The Office 365 Management API is not supported at this time. Please refer to one of the public solutions in the [Microsoft Sentinel Github Repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-Sentinel/tree/master/DataConnectors).

### Details

This section creates the request for the connector. The request body is made up of:

1. API Endpoint: Mandatory, The endpoint URI for the API that provides the data.
2. Rate Limit: Optional, defines the number of calls or queries allowed in seconds.
3. Query Window in Minutes: Optional, defines the availability query window in minutes. Minimum value is 5.
4. HTTP Method: Mandatory, The request method used for fetching the data.
5. Query Time Format: Mandatory, defines the format used to define the query time. Value can be a string or in UnixTimestamp/UnixTimestampInMills format to indicate the query start and end time. (Ex. YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS)
6. Start Time Attribute Name: Optional, defines the name of the attribute that defines the query start time.
7. End Time Attribute Name: Optional, defines the name of the attribute that defines the query time interval.
8. Retry Count: Optional, defines the number of request retries to attempt if neeed.
9. Timeout in Seconds: Optional, defines the request timeout in seconds.
10. Query Parameters: Optional, defines the parameters passed in the query in the eventsJsonPaths path.
 
Any value entered will be compiled into a variable for the template. If anything is left empty, it will not be included.

For more information, please refer to the [request section of the public document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/create-codeless-connector?tabs=deploy-via-arm-template%2Cconnect-via-the-azure-portal#request-configuration).

parameters.name: request
parameters.query:
let content = datatable(key: string, value:dynamic)[
    "apiEndpoint", "{apiEndpoint}",
    "rateLimitQPS", int({rateLimitOPS}),
    "queryWindowInMIn", int({queryWindowInMin}),
    "httpMethod", "{httpMethod}",
    "queryTimeFormat", "{queryTimeFormat}",
    "startTimeAttributeName", "{startTimeAttributeName}",
    "endTimeAttributeName", "{endTimeAttributeName}",
    "retryCount", int({retryCount}),
    "timeoutInSeconds", int({timeoutInSeconds}),
    "Accept", "application/json",
    ];
content

parameters.name: responseJSON
parameters.query:
let response = datatable(key:string, value:string)[
    "eventsJsonPaths", "{eventsJsonPaths}",
    "format", "{format}"
    ];
response
| where isnotempty(value)
| extend response = bag_pack(key, value)
| extend response = iff(response has 'eventsJsonPaths', todynamic(strcat('{"eventsJsonPaths":[', replace_regex(tostring(split(response, ':')[1]), '}', ''), ']}')), response)
| extend response = todynamic(response)
| summarize response = make_bag(response)

content.json:
### Details

This section will define how the response is processed from the request. The response body is made up of:

1. JSON Path: The JSON Path that can be used to parse out the data in the API response.
2. Format: The expected format of the response.

All values entered will be consolidated into a variable for the template. Anything left empty will not be included.

For a quick reference to JSONPaths, please refer to [this sample document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/jsonpath).

For more information, please refer to the [response section of the public document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/create-codeless-connector?tabs=deploy-via-arm-template%2Cconnect-via-the-azure-portal#response-configuration).

parameters.name: responseCSV
parameters.query:
let response = datatable(key:string, value:string)[
    "eventsJsonPaths", "{eventsJsonPaths}",
    "format", "{format}",
    "CsvDelimiter", "{CsvDelimiter}",
    "HasCsvBoundary", "{HasCsvBoundary}",
    "HasCsvHeader", "{HasCsvHeader}",
    "CsvEscape", "{CsvEscape}"
    ];
response
| extend value = iff(key has 'CsvEscape' and isempty(value), '"', value)
| where isnotempty(value)
| extend response = bag_pack(key, value)
| summarize response = make_bag(response)

content.json:
### Details

This section will define how the response is processed from the request. The response body is made up of:


1. Format: The expected format of the response.
2. CSV Delimiter: Optional, if response format is CSV and you want to change the default CSV delimiter of ",".
3. Has CSV Boundary: Optional, indicate if CSV data has a boundary.
4. Has CSV Header: Optional, indicate if CSV data has a header, default is True.
5. CSV Escape: Optional, escape character for a field boundary, default is ". For example, a CSV with headers id,name,avg and a row of data containing spaces like 1,"my name",5.5 requires the " field boundary.

All values entered will be consolidated into a variable for the template. Anything left empty will not be included.

For a quick reference to JSONPaths, please refer to [this sample document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/jsonpath).

For more information, please refer to the [response section of the public document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/data-connector-connection-rules-reference#response-configuration).

### Details

This section will configure the pagination of the data brought in via the connector. The paging body will vary depending on the type chosen. The available options are:
- LinkHeader
- PersistentLinkheader
- NextPageToken
- PersistentToken
- NextPageUrl
- Offset

If you are unsure about which method to use or if one is needed, please refer to the API documentation for the endpoint that you are calling.

For more information, please refer to the [paging section of the public document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/create-codeless-connector?tabs=deploy-via-arm-template%2Cconnect-via-the-azure-portal#paging-configuration).

### Details

LinkHeader or PersistentLinkheader has been chosen for the paging method. The body of this section is made up of:

- Field: Optional, specifies the field that contains the value (value, body, etc).
- Link Header Token JSON Path: Optional, defines the JSON path to link header in the response JSON if the header isn't already defined..
- Page Size: Defines the paging size for the link header.
- Page Size Parameter Name: Optional, defines the name of the page size parameter.

All values entered will be consolidated into a variable for the template. Anything that is left empty will not be included.

### Details

NextPageToken or PersistentToken has been selected as the paging method. The body of this section is made up of:

- Token Page Size:  Defines the paging size.
- Next Page Token Response Header: Optional, defines the next page token header name in the response.
- Next Page Token JSON Path: Optional, defines the path to a next page token JSON.
- Next Page Parameter Name: Optional, determines the next page name in the request.
- Has Next Flag JSON Path: Optional, defines the JSON path to link header in the response JSON if the header isn't already defined..
- Next Page Request Header: Optional, determines the next page header name in the request.

All values entered will be consolidated into a variable for the template. Anything that is left empty will not be included.

parameters.name: URLNextPageUrlQueryParametersTemplate
parameters.label: Next Page Url Query Parameters Template

content.json:
### Details

NextPageUrl has been selected as the paging method. The body of this section is made up of:

- URLPageSize: Defines the paging size.
- Page Size Parameter Name: Optional, defines the name of the page size parameter.
- URL Next Page Url: Optional, determines the next page URL if it is different from the initial URL.
- Next Page Url Query Parameters: Optional, determines the next page URL's query parameters if it's different from the initial request's URL. Define the string in the dictionary ```<string, object> format: {'<attr_name>': <val>, '<attr_name>': <val>... }```
- Next Page Para Name: Optional, determines the next page name in the request.
- Has Next Flag JSON Path: Optional, defines the path to the HasNextPage flag attribute.
- Next Page Request Header: Optional, determines the next page header name in the request.

All values entered will be consolidated into a variable for the template. Anything that is left empty will not be included.

### Details

Offset has been selected as the paging method. The body of this section is made up of:

- Offset Page Size: Defines the paging size.
- Page Size Parameter Name: Optional, defines the name of the page size parameter.
- Offset Parameter Name: Optional, defines the name of the offset parameter.


All values entered will be consolidated into a variable for the template. Anything that is left empty will not be included.

parameters.name: LHPaging
TokenPaging
parameters.query:
let pagingType_ = dynamic('{pagingType}');
let NextPageValues = datatable(key:string, value:dynamic)[
    "pagingType", "{pagingType}",
    "PageSize", "{TokenPageSize}",
    "NextPageTokenResponseHeader", "{TokenNextPageTokenResponseHeader}",
    "NextPageTokenJSONPath", "{TokenNextPageTokenJSONPath}",
    "NextPageResponseHeader", "{TokenNextPageResponseHeader}",
    "NextPageParaName", "{TokenNextPageParaName}",
    "HasNextFlagJSONPath", "{TokenHasNextFlagJSONPath}",
    "NextPageRequestHeader", "{TokenNextPageRequestHeader}"
    ];
let NPChecker = NextPageValues | where pagingType_ == 'NextPageToken' or pagingType_ == 'PersistentToken' | where isnotempty(value);
NPChecker
| extend paging = bag_pack(key, value)
| summarize paging = make_bag(paging)

parameters.name: URLPaging
parameters.query:
let pagingType_ = dynamic('{pagingType}');
let URL = datatable(key:string, value:string)[
    "pagingType", "{pagingType}",
    "PageSize", "{URLPageSize}",
    "PageSizeParameterName", "{URLPageSizeParameterName}",
    "NextPageUrl", "{URLNextPageUrl}",
    "NextPageUrlQueryParameters", "{URLNextPageUrlQueryParameters}",
    "NextPageParaName", "{URLNextPageParaName}",
    "HasNextFlagJSONFlag", "{URLHasNextFlagJSONFlag}",
    "NextPageRequestHeader", "{URLNextPageRequestHeader}",
    "NextPageUrlQueryParametersTemplate", "{URLNextPageUrlQueryParametersTemplate}"
    ];
let URLChecker = URL | where pagingType_ == 'NextPageUrl' | where isnotempty(value);
URLChecker
| extend paging = bag_pack(key, value)
| summarize paging = make_bag(paging)

parameters.name: OffsetPaging

content.json:
### Details

This section will configure the authentication used by the connector in order to poll the data. The current options are:

- APIKey
- OAuth2

### Details

APIKey: Optional in the builder, defines the API key that will be used in the connector. This item is only used for testing within the builder workbook. The value will be needed again when enabling the connector in the UI.
APIKeyName: Optional, defines the name of your API key, as one of the following values:
	- XAuthToken
	- Authorization
IsAPIKeyInPostPayload: Determines where your API key is defined.
	- True: API key is defined in the POST request payload
	- False: API key is defined in the header

### Details

1. FlowName: Mandatory, defines an OAuth2 flow. Automatically set by the builder.
2. Client ID: Optional in the builder, defines the client ID that will be used to fetch the token and data. This is only used in the testing section at the bottom of this tab. The client ID will be needed again when enabling the connector in the UI.
3. Client Secret: Optional in the builder, defines the client secret that will be used to fetch the token and data. This is only used in the testing section at the bottom of this tab. The client secret will be needed again when enabling the connector in the UI.
4. TokenEndpoint: Mandatory for OAuth2 auth types, defines the OAuth2 token service endpoint.
5. RedirectionEndpoint: Optional, defines a redirection endpoint during onboarding.
6. Scope: Defines the scope of where the API is pointing to.
7. GrantType: Defines the type of token granting. Default value is client_credentials but may also be authorization_code
8. AuthorizationEndpoint: Optional, defines the OAuth2 authorization service endpoint. Used only during onboarding or when renewing a refresh token.
9. Is Client Secret in Header: Optional, default is false. Determines whether the client_id and client_secret values are defined in the header.
10. Token Endpoint Query Parameters: Optional, Optional, define query parameters when calling OAuth2 token service endpoint. Define a string in the serialized dictionary```<string, object> format: {'<attr_name>': <serialized val>, '<attr_name>': <serialized val>, ... }```
11. Authorization Endpoint Query Parameters: Optional, Optional. defines query parameters when calling an OAuth2 authorization service endpoint. Used only during onboarding or when renewing a refresh token. Define a string in the serialized dictionary```<string, object> format:{'<attr_name>': <serialized val>, '<attr_name>': <serialized val>, ... }```

For more information, please refer to the [OAuth2 section of the public document](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/create-codeless-connector?tabs=deploy-via-arm-template%2Cconnect-via-the-azure-portal#oauth2-authtype-parameters).

parameters.name: basicAuth
parameters.query:
let basic = datatable(key:string, value:dynamic)[
    "type", "Basic",
    "Username", "{Username}",
    "Password", "{Password}"
    ]
;
basic
| where isnotempty(key)
| where isnotempty(value)
| project auth = bag_pack(key, value)
| summarize auth = make_bag(auth)

parameters.name: apiKeyAuth
parameters.query:
let apiKey = datatable(key:string, value:dynamic)[
    "type", "APIKey",
    "APIKey", "[parameters('apiKey')]",
    "APIKeyName", "{APIKeyName}",
    "isAPIKeyInPostPayload", "{isAPIKeyInPostPayload}"
    ]
;
apiKey
| where isnotempty(key)
| where isnotempty(value)
| project auth = bag_pack(key, value)
| summarize auth = make_bag(auth)

parameters.name: oAuth
parameters.query:
let OAuth2 = datatable(key:string, value:dynamic)[
    "type", "OAuth2",
    "ClientId", "{ClientId}",
    "ClientSecret", "{ClientSecret}",
    "Scope", "{Scope}",
    "RedirectUri", "{RedirectUri}",
    "GrantType", "{GrantType}",
    "TokenEndpoint", "{TokenEndpoint}",
    "TokenEndpointHeaders", 'Content-Type":"application/x-www-form-urlencoded',
    "tokenEndpointQueryParameters", dynamic({TokenEndpointQueryParameters}),
    "isClientSecretInHeader", "{IsClientSecretInHeader}",
    "AuthorizationEndpoint", "{AuthorizationEndpoint}",
    "AuthorizationEndpointQueryParameters", dynamic({AuthorizationEndpointQueryParameters}),
    "FlowName", "AuthCode"
    ]
;
OAuth2
| where isnotempty(key)
| where isnotempty(value)
| project auth = bag_pack(key, value)

content.json:
### Details

The section below provides pre-configured API actions that take on the value of the API endpoint, authentication method, and credentials to test if the information is valid and if a response can be given.

*Note: If CORS is not enabled on the API endpoint, chances are that there will be an error give within the testing section.*

### Details

The connector summary section will configure general details for the connector, such as title, publisher, and more. </br>

- Title: The title that the connector will have.
- Publisher: Publisher of the connector. Can use Custom or the provider of the data.
- Description: The description that will be shown within the connector gallery.
- Graph visualization: The configuration for the graph that is shown for data ingest. The values below are pre-defined and don't need to be changed. They can be if more queries are desired. The only value that needs to be changed is the query table name.

parameters.name: graphQueriesTableName
parameters.label: Query Table Name
parameters.query: print '{FetchTableName}'

content.json:
### Details

These values are pre-configured. The table name will need to be updated to reflect the table being used for the connector. If additional queries are desired, they can be added but are required to be JSON format.
##### Required Connector Permissions

parameters.name: permissionDisplayText
parameters.label: Permission Display Text
parameters.value: Read and Write Permissions are Required

parameters.name: permissions
parameters.query:
let permissions = datatable(key:string, value:dynamic)
[ 
    "resourceProvider", "{ResourceProvider}",
    "permissionDisplayText","{permissionDisplayText}",
    "providerDisplayName", "{providerDisplayName}",
    "scope", "{scope}",
    "write", "{write}",
    "read", "{read}",
    "delete", "{delete}"
    ];
permissions
| project holder = bag_pack(key, value)
| summarize request = make_bag(holder)

content.json:
### Details

This section will configure the permissions portion of the data connector. These values are pre-defined and don't need to be changed.

### Details

This section will configure the instructions that appear on the connector details page. These values are pre-defined and don't need to be changed.

parameters.name: UserInDescription
parameters.label: Description
parameters.value: Follow the steps listed in order to connect the connector. Enter the requested values in the boxes below.

parameters.name: InDescription
parameters.query: print description = strcat('{UserInDescription}', 'This connector is sending data via the {DCR2:name} data collection rule and the {DCESelect:name} data collection endpoint.')

content.json:
### Details

This area defines the UI for the instructions on the connector. These instructions will be associated with connectors that do not use authentication and will just have a connect/disconnect button.

### Details

This area defines the UI for the instructions on the connector. These instructions will be associated with connectors that use basic authentication. The connector will contain input boxes for the authentication endpoint, the username, and the password needed for authentication. Once entered, the connect/disconnect button can be used.

parameters.name: apiKeyInstructions
parameters.label: Instructions

content.json:
### Details

This area defines the UI for the instructions on the connector. These instructions will be associated with connectors that use APIKey authentication. The connector will contain input boxes for the authentication endpoint and the API key. Once entered, the connect/disconnect button can be used.

### Details

These instructions will be associated with connectors that use OAuth2 authentication. The connector will contain input boxes for the client ID, client secret, and authorization code if needed. Once entered, the connect/disconnect button can be used.

### Note

Please note: Deploying this template does not enable the connector. This will just deploy the connector components and create the UI. You will need to go to the data connector gallery and deploy the connector.

### Note

Please note: Deploying this template does not enable the connector. This will just deploy the connector components and create the UI. You will need to go to the data connector gallery and deploy the connector.
